column2: Vaŭkavýsk; Russian: Волковыск; Polish: Wołkowysk; Lithuanian: Valkaviskas; Yiddish: וואלקאוויסק‎; names in other languages) is one of the oldest towns in southwestern Belarus and the capital of the Vawkavysk district. It is located on the Wołkowyja River
column3: roughly 98 kilometres (61 mi) from Grodno and 271 kilometres (168 mi) from Minsk. Its population is estimated at 43
column4: 826 inhabitants.Vawkavysk was first unofficially mentioned in the Turov Annals in 1005 and this year is widely accepted as the founding year for Vawkavysk. At that time Volkovysk was a city-fortress on the border of the Baltic and the Slavic ethnic groups. Since 12th century
column5: Volkovysk was the center of a small princedom. The Hypatian Chronicle mentions the city in 1252.

column1: The name is thought to be derived from the local dialect for the phrases for searching for wolves ("wołków isk") or the howling of wolves ("wołków wisk"). Old Belarusian tradition refers to the area surrounding Vawkavysk as once being occupied by vast forestry filled with wolves. The river flowing through the town was named Wołkowyja. This also explains the appearance of a wolf's head or body on the town's coat of arms.However
column2: modern scholars have also hypothesized that the name of Vawkavysk was of more recent origin and hence succeeded the original legend. Vawkavysk was mentioned in a manuscript written by the priest D. Bułakowski at the end of the 16th or beginning of the 17th century. It was stored in the Sapieha family's library in Ruzhany Palace
column3: where it was translated into Russian in 1881 and published in a Vilnius gazette. According to the manuscript
column4: in the place where Vawkavysk is now situated
column5: were large swathes of forest
column6: through which flowed the now non-existent Nietupa River
column7: and consisted of winding travel routes on which travelers were frequently attacked. Within this forest
column10: had their hide-out. A prince named Vladislav Zabeyko
column12: tracked down the robbers and hung them on trees for the birds to feed upon. A settlement was built in the location of the robbers' hide-out
column14: and occupied by slaves. At the execution site
column15: a large stone was placed but
column17: was later broken up to be used to build a temple.

column1: Vawkavysk is located in the valley basin of the Wołkowyja river near its confluence with the Ros River
column3: in turn
column4: directly north about 25 kilometres (16 mi) to the Neman River. The historical core of Vawkavysk lies on the left bank of the river. The town has been expanding to the west and south. The town has an urban area of 79 square kilometres (31 sq mi)

column1: On the left bank of the Wołkowyja
column2: the town is surrounded on three sides by hilly terrain
column3: while the highest point of Vawkavysk proper is Swedish Mountain
column4: located on the southeastern outskirts of town
column5: with its height from the base to the top of its defensive wall varying from 28 to 32.5 metres (92 to 107 ft). The mountain's base is round with a diameter of about 350 metres (1
column6: 150 ft). A flat top of "the Swedish mountain" nearly round and is 55 metres (180 ft) wide east to west. The perimeter of the flat top is surrounded by a powerful defensive wall broken in the south by the entrance. The mountains of Zamchishche (Castle Mountain) and Muravelnik (Mouse Mountain) lie to the west and east of Swedish Mountain
column7: respectively.

column1: Vawkavysk lies in the warm summer continental or hemiboreal (Dfb) climate zone
column2: with four seasons and uniformly spread precipitation. Monthly averages range from -5.0 °C (23 °F) in January to 17.9 °C (64.2 °F) in July. There are
column3: on average
column4: 95 days a year when there is snow cover. Vawkavysk receives about 632 millimetres (24.9 in) of precipitation a year. The average period of vegetation is 194 days
column5: and lasts from April to October. The highest officially recorded temperature in Vawkavysk was 36 °C (96.8 °F) in 1959
column6: while on the other end
column7: the lowest temperature was -38 °C (-36.4 °F) in 1950.

column1: Originally three fortified settlements were started here prior to the 10th century. Swedish Mountain
column3: are considered territory that chronicles the town known as Vawkavysk. Swedish Mountain is a remnant of one of these fortifications. Gradually
column4: as the settlement grew
column5: the boundaries of the town extended to the neighboring hill of Zamchishcha. Industrical and commercial sites were located at the foot of Swedish Mountain along its northern
column6: eastern
column7: and southern sides. Muravelnike was also inhabited
column8: but was not as populated as Swedish Mountain and Zamchishcha. Due to flooding of the Wołkowyja River
column9: there are no other known archaeological sites.

column1: Vawkavysk is one of the oldest towns of Eastern Europe and has played a role in the political development of medieval Slavic civilization. It is believed that Vawkavysk was founded in the 10th century. The origin of the town is obscured by legends
column2: one of which tells about a prince Vladislav Zabeyko who
column3: in 738
column4: found robbers named Voloka and Visek and killed them. In the place of their shelter
column5: 10 huts were built
column6: which expanded into a settlement. According to it
column7: the name Vawkavysk is derived from the names of the two robbers. Another legend states that the town was founded by the King of Lithuania

column1: There is little historical evidence pertaining to the period when the town was founded. Archaeological excavations conducted at the site of the ancient town attest that a Slavic settlement had already existed in the area by the late 10th century based on the dwellings and defensive works which were discovered during the excavation. Vawkavysk was first unofficially mentioned in the Turov Annals in 1005 and this year has been widely accepted as the town's founding year. Vawkavysk turned into a town and became a center of crafts and trades in the early 12th century. In 1224 and 1241
column2: the Mongol invasion of Rus led by Batu Khan destroyed Vawkavysk and its fortress.Vawkavysk lies in a region formerly referred to as Black Ruthenia that was subjugated to various invading forces of Baltic and Slavic tribes. At various times
column3: the town was influenced by the Principality of Polotsk and Galicia-Volhynia. On the nights of 15 and 16 February 1038
column4: the town was destroyed by a Baltic tribe of Yatvingians. Up until 1084
column5: this territory belonged under Slavic Kievan Rus and later became a dependent vassal state. After Mindaugas conquered the area in 1239
column6: it was incorporated into what would later become the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and was administered from Navahrudak from the 1240s to the 1250s.

column1: Vawkavysk's location on the border between Lithuania and neighboring Galicia-Volhynia resulted in frequent fighting over these territories. The Ipatiev Chronicle mentions Vawkavysk in connection with an invasion of the Galicia-Volhynian prince Daniel Romanovich Galitsky and his brother Vasilko in 1252. Power exchanged hands periodically during the years of 1254-1258 between the princes of these two kingdoms. The chronicle continues with describing that a peace treaty was signed in 1254 where the Grand Duke of Lithuania
column3: transferred Vawkavysk
column4: along with several other towns
column5: to Daniel's son
column6: Roman Danylovich Galitsky. Sometime after this event
column9: who acknowledged himself as a vassal of the Grand Duke of Lithuania
column10: became ruler of Vawkavysk. Prince Gleb participated in a Galicia-Volhynian campaign against the Yatvingians in 1256.

column3: that Vawkavysk and Slonim settled as vassal states of Lithuania  with Vaišvilkas again reigning from Navahrudak as a vassal of Mindaugas. In 1260
column4: Vaišvilkas and another Lithuanian prince
column5: Toth
column6: captured and killed Roman
column7: which resulted in Daniel marching to the upper reaches of the Neman River to recapture Vawkavysk and take Gleb as prisoner. The chronicle fails to explain what ended this particular campaign. Meanwhile
column9: Mindaugas of Lithuania was murdered. In the chaos that followed Mindaugas' assassination
column10: the lands of the Grand Duchy were in disarray
column11: with both local and foreign rulers struggling for power. Additionally
column13: Daniel died and his son Svarn Danylovich Galitsky received nominal overlordship over all of the Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia as its duke
column14: including Vawkavysk. Ownership of the town in 1269 belonged to prince Vladimir.Following Svarn's loss of the throne in 1269
column15: his brother Lev I of Galicia entered into conflict with Lithuania. In 1274–1276 he fought a war with the new Lithuanian ruler Traidenis but was defeated
column16: and Lithuania annexed the territory of Black Ruthenia with its city of Navahrudak.

column1: During a campaign against the Lithuanians in 1277
column2: the Rus army and their princes
column3: Mstislav Danylovich
column4: another son of Daniel; Vladimir Vasilkovich; and Yuri Lvovich
column5: stopped for the night in Vawkavysk. The last time Vawkavysk is mentioned in the Ipatiev Chronicle is when Lithuanian Grand Duke Butigeidis transferred Vawkavysk to prince Mstislav Danylovich in exchange for peace in 1289.

column1: Vawkavysk came under the rule of Grand Duke Vytenis and became part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania from 1293.It was from a now non-existent castle in Vawkavysk that
column3: Jogaila sent his envoys to Kraków to ask for the hand of the Queen of Poland
column4: Jadwiga. He declared that he along with the Lithuanian people was to adopt the Catholic faith
column5: and received the Polish envoys after a long-awaited decision on 11 January 1386. In 1386 Jogaila was baptized as Władysław II Jagiełło in Kraków and became King of Poland. Jagiełło
column6: while in Vawkavysk in 1387
column7: ordered the destruction of pagan deities.

column1: In 1409 the town was attacked and plundered by the Teutonic Knights under the command of Hochmeister Ulrich von Jungingen and its residents taken captive. On 16 March 1410
column2: the town was seized again and burnt under the command of Ordensmarschall Frederic von Wallenrode and its residents were murdered. On 15 July 1410
column3: the Vawkavysk banner participated in the Battle of Grunwald against the Teutonic Order. In 1430 the church of St. Nicholas was built. Vawkavysk was included in the composition of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in 1441 after being under its authority since 1258.

column1: In 1503 Vawkavysk was granted Magdeburg city rights by Polish king Alexander I Jagiellon. These rights were confirmed by different kings up to 1773. The town received its personal coat of arms of a wolf's head on a blue background. In 1507
column2: Vawkavysk became part of the Nowogródek Voivodeship and was capital of Wołkowysk powiat until 1795. By 1513
column3: Vawkavysk had 9 streets. A church was mentioned as having existed since 1536
column4: while a monastery of Jesuits was founded in 1598. From 1566
column5: Vawkavysk was also a venue for General Sejmiks
column6: which provincial delegates and senators attended
column7: that were held for the whole of Lithuania.  The most prominent nobility of Vawkavysk at this time included the Gołgowski and Piotrowicz families.

column1: The Union of Lublin was signed July 1
column3: in Lublin
column4: Poland
column5: and created a single state
column6: the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. It replaced the personal union of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania with a real union and an elective monarchy
column7: since Sigismund II Augustus
column9: remained childless after three marriages. Subsequent to this
column10: Vawkavysk became a town within the Commonwealth.

column1: The 17th century was a very difficult time in the history of Vawkavysk
column3: and the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in general. The region became the scene of many wars.  It was during this time that the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth entered into a series of mid-17th century campaigns
column4: known as The Deluge
column5: consisting of uprisings
column6: invasions and Northern Wars with Russia and Sweden. Following the popular uprising led by Bohdan Khmelnytsky in Ukraine
column7: the rebellion brought into focus the rivalry between Russia and the Commonwealth for hegemony over Ukraine and over the eastern Slavic lands in general. In October 1653 the Russian zemsky sobor declared war on the Commonwealth and in June 1654
column8: the forces of Tsar Alexis of Russia invaded the eastern half of Poland-Lithuania
column9: starting the Russo-Polish War of 1654-67. During this time
column10: Vawkavysk was captured twice by Russian troops in 1655 and 1662 and left heavily damaged.

column8: Vawkavysk was destroyed and burned by the army of King Charles X Gustav of Sweden. The administrative center of the town was a castle on the river near the road to Izabelin
column9: which was destroyed alongside the town.

column1: Vawkavysk eventually found itself within the Russian Empire in 1795 following the third partition of Poland. It was placed under the administration of the Slonim Governorate as a province and became the capital of its own district within the Lithuania-Grodno Governorate in 1802.During the French invasion of Russia in 1812
column2: Vawkavysk housed the headquarters of General Pyotr Bagration
column3: commander of the 2nd Russian Army. From 17 June to 15 November [O.S. 3 November] 1812
column4: the town housed Napoleon's army. On 2–4 November 1812
column5: during a battle between the French and Russian forces
column6: Vawkavysk was burned. Russian General Fabian Gottlieb von Osten-Sacken defeated the VII Saxon Corps of French General Jean Reynier. The Congress of Vienna in 1815 confirmed Vawkavysk's belonging to Russia.

column4: and a pharmacy. In 1845 the town received new Russian coat of arms. As of 1860 Vawkavysk consisted of 492 homes

column1: In 1863 a company from Vawkavysk under the command of Gustaw Strawiński took part in the January Uprising.

In 1885 the town began construction on what would become an important railway junction with the building of a railway line from Baranovichi to Białystok and opened its railway station in 1886. By 1891 Vawkavysk had 19 industrial enterprises operating. In 1906 construction began of a railway line to Siedlce and upon completion in 1907 the town was an important railway junction.
=== World War I and the Interbellum ===

column2: Vawkavysk was the headquarters of the commander-in-chief of the North-Western Front. In the autumn of 1915
column3: the town was occupied by German troops. Following the collapse of Imperial Russia in 1917
column4: the subsequent emergence of the new Bolshevik government of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic
column5: and the signing of the armistice between Russia and the Central Powers
column6: Vawkavysk and the surrounding area temporarily laid within Russian territory. The signing of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk on 3 March 1918
column7: between Russia and the Central Powers (Germany
column10: and Turkey) ended Russia's participation in World War I. In this peace treaty
column11: Russia renounced all territorial claims in Finland (which it had already acknowledged)
column15: and Ukraine. During the negotiations of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk
column16: Belarus first declared independence under German occupation on 25 March 1918
column17: forming the Belarusian People's Republic. Meanwhile
column18: an independent Polish state was restored in 1918
column19: but its borders were not formally determined.

column1: By 1919 Bolsheviks took control over Belarus and forced the country's democratic government into exile. Immediately afterwards
column3: and the territory of Belarus was divided between Poland and Soviet Russia. On 8 February 1919 Vawkavysk was occupied by Polish troops. The town was then captured by the 16th Bolshevik Army on 24 July 1920 and subsequently recaptured on 27 September 1920 by the 3rd Legions Infantry Division under the command of General Leon Berbecki.

column1: The Treaty of Riga was signed in Riga on 18 March 1921
column3: Soviet Russia (acting also on behalf of Soviet Belarus) and Soviet Ukraine. The treaty ended the Polish-Bolshevik War. Following this
column4: Vawkavysk became a part of the interwar Second Polish Republic in the period between 1919 and 1939. Wołkowysk powiat was part of the Białystok Voivodeship and the seat of gmina Biskupice.

column1: On 8 December 1922 the 3rd Regiment of Mounted Riflemen entered the town's barracks. In 1924 the 8th Cavalry Brigade Command was created. As of 1939 Vawkavysk contained an iron foundry
column3: two sawmills
column4: and other small businesses. On the outskirts of town was a cement plant
column5: which was considered one of the most powerful companies in Western Belarus.

column1: Upon the invasion of the Second Polish Republic by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union
column2: the Reserve Cavalry Brigade "Wołkowysk" was formed. Vawkavysk came under Soviet occupation on 18 September 1939 as a result of the German–Soviet Treaty of Friendship
column3: Cooperation and Demarcation. On 2 November 1939 Vawkavysk
column4: along with the rest of Western Belarus
column5: was adopted into the USSR and on 14 November 1939 was adopted into the BSSR. Vawkavysk became the regional capital of the Białystok region within the BSSR on 15 January 1940. The town was a point of detention and deportation of German and Polish prisoners-of-war and citizens in POW camp 281 by the Red Army until 1941.

column1: Vawkavysk was occupied by the German Army on 28 June 1941. At that time
column2: about 7000 Jews lived in the town

column4: mostly but not entirely Jews

column6: the Germans
column7: with some assistance by local Christians
column8: murdered several dozen Jews within the first week and another 200 in mid July
column9: mostly business and professional men along with those who had handicaps.   That fall
column11: forcing the town's Jewish population into it.  Five to ten families lived in each residence.  The Germans conscripted Jews for forced labor demolishing buildings and constructing new ones.

column1: The ghetto became a transit ghetto for Jews of Kreis Wolkowysk.  About 20
column2: 000 Jews passed through; most were sent on to Treblinka where they were immediately murdered.  Others died in the ghetto from typhus or starvation.  In December 1942
column3: part of the transit camp was converted to a closed ghetto for about 2000 Jews
column4: mostly essential male workers who were allowed to leave each day to go to work sites.  Most of the rest still in the transit ghetto were also sent to Treblinka though some were murdered on site.  As many as 500 were transferred to the Bialystok ghetto
column5: some of those escaping to the local forest.  Several women cut their hair and dressed as men to be allowed out as male laborers.

column2: the final group of ghetto dwellers was sent to Auschwitz where most were murdered immediately.  About 70 Jews  of the original 7000 Jewish residents survived the war.  Some of the survivors had fled to the Soviet Union at the beginning of the war; others were fighting in the forests as partisans and a few survived Auschwitz.During the Białystok Operation
column3: on 14 July 1944
column4: the 2nd Belarusian Front of the Red Army was able to recapture the town. The town became the regional center of Grodno region of the BSSR on 20 September 1944.
